97048: Mana Crypt.author: Pontiac

This card won me alot of games, put it in a deck with the following

Mana Excel

Sol Ring, Mox Jet, Mox Sapphire, Mox Ruby, Mox Pearl, Mox Emerald, Mox Opal, Mox Diamond, Mana Vault, Grim Monolith, Black Lotus, Lotus Petal, Chrome Mox and 4 Dark Rituals.

Card Excel

Windfall, Timetwister, Wheel of Fortune, Memory Jar, Ancestral Recall, yadda, yadda.

Your first turn will pown every time, your going to have lots of mana to do something your opponent will not enjoy or most likely dump your hand and draw 7 till you do.

Back in the day we called it Type 1, now it's Vintage I guess, but either way I used Mana Crypt. It can decide a game on the first turn, who cares about 3 damage, the game is over by 3rd turn max in that format, if can't do that then don't play type 1 or at least think your deck over again.

97050: Nalathni Dragon.author: MadMageQc
97050: Nalathni Dragon.text_parsed:
2010/01/16: Gatherer wrongly lists this card as not playable in any tournament format. It is actually fully legal in Legacy and Vintage. From the Magic tournament rules :

3.3 Authorized Cards
Players may use any cards from special sets, supplements, and promotional printings that, unaltered, meet the following conditions:
• The card is published by Wizards of the Coast
• The card has a standard Magic back
• The card does not have squared corners
• The card has black or white borders
• The card is not damaged or modified in a way that might make it marked
• The card is otherwise legal for the tournament as defined by the format

Nalathni Dragon, as well as Sewers of Estark and Windseeker Centaur are tournament-legal Magic cards, because they are published by WotC, they have Magic card backs, they do not have squared corners and they have black borders. They are legal in the Legacy and Vintage formats because all tournament-legal Magic cards are legal in those (unless they appear on the Banned and Restricted lists of course, and these three cards don't). Their sister card Mana Crypt is correctly classified as restricted in Vintage only because it is a more high-profile card that sees extensive play in that format.

97050: Nalathni Dragon.author: DarthParallax
97050: Nalathni Dragon.text_parsed:
OK, I hate to be a real pain in the ass here- for the people who understand banding, you can skip this comment. For everyone else, observe:


Any creatures with banding, and up to one without, can attack in a band. Bands are blocked as a group. If any creatures with banding you control are blocking or being blocked by a creature, you divide that creature's combat damage, not its controller, among any of the creatures it's being blocked by or is blocking.


Alright, here's my problem. After reading this 12 times, I finally know what it does. The first 11 times I didn't know what it meant to 'divide a controller'. Here's my proposal for new banding text:

Any creatures with banding, and up to one without, can attack in a band. Bands are blocked as a group. If any creatures with banding you control are blocking or being blocked by a creature, you, not its controller, divide that creature's combat damage among any of the creatures it's being blocked by or is blocking.

God banding sucks xP
I mean, ok, it might be somewhat useful, but it's not worth the headache it takes to read the damn reminder text. I swear to god, if anyone plays Duh on a creature with banding, they totally deserve to be kicked in the nuts.

If any creatures with banding you control are blocking or being blocked by a creature, [b]you divide that creature's combat damage, not its controller[/b], among any of the creatures it's being blocked by or is blocking.


Alright, here's my problem. After reading this 12 times, I finally know what it does. The first 11 times I didn't know what it meant to 'divide a controller'.  Here's my proposal for new banding text:

Any creatures with banding, and up to one without, can attack in a band. Bands are blocked as a group. If any creatures with banding you control are blocking or being blocked by a creature, [b]you, not its controller, divide that creature's combat damage[/b] among any of the creatures it's being blocked by or is blocking.

God banding sucks xP 
I mean, ok, it might be somewhat useful, but it's not worth the headache it takes to read the damn reminder text. I swear to god, if anyone plays [autocard]Duh[/autocard] on a creature with banding, they totally deserve to be kicked in the nuts.

97052: Questing Phelddagrif.text_parsed: I'll use this to point out something interesting about the backs of Magic cards. See that pen mark over the T in "DECKMASTER"? It wasn't supposed to be there, but someone accidentally marked the logo with a pen before they started printing it on the backs. They realized it after a large print run, and because the backs of all cards must be identical, that blue scribble has been there ever since.

97054: Sewers of Estark.author: MadMageQc
97054: Sewers of Estark.text_parsed:
2010/01/16: Gatherer wrongly lists this card as not playable in any tournament format. It is actually fully legal in Legacy and Vintage. From the Magic tournament rules :

3.3 Authorized Cards
Players may use any cards from special sets, supplements, and promotional printings that, unaltered, meet the following conditions:
• The card is published by Wizards of the Coast
• The card has a standard Magic back
• The card does not have squared corners
• The card has black or white borders
• The card is not damaged or modified in a way that might make it marked
• The card is otherwise legal for the tournament as defined by the format

Sewers of Estark, as well as Nalathni Dragon and Windseeker Centaur, are tournament-legal Magic cards, because they are published by WotC, they have Magic card backs, they do not have squared corners and they have black borders. They are legal in the Legacy and Vintage formats because all tournament-legal Magic cards are legal in those (unless they appear on the Banned and Restricted lists of course, and these three cards don't). Their sister card Mana Crypt is correctly classified as restricted in Vintage only because it is a more high-profile card that sees extensive play in that format.

• The card has black or white borders
• The card is not damaged or modified in a way that might make it marked
• The card is otherwise legal for the tournament as defined by the format

Windseeker Centaur, as well as [autocard]Nalathni Dragon[/autocard] and [autocard]Sewers of Estark[/autocard], are tournament-legal Magic cards, because they are published by WotC, they have Magic card backs, they do not have squared corners and they have black borders. They are legal in the Legacy and Vintage formats because all tournament-legal Magic cards are legal in those (unless they appear on the Banned and Restricted lists of course, and these three cards don't). Their sister card [autocard]Mana Crypt[/autocard] is correctly classified as restricted in Vintage and banned in Legacy only because it is a more high-profile card that sees extensive play in that format.

I expect a creature that is too slow to help me much against aggresive creature decks when it would be large, since it's expensive. I expect a creature that is useless against controlling decks that run few creatures - which is when you'll have time to play it. It's interesting because unlike most of these Keldon Warlord variants, it's all players. Certainly better in multiplayer, and you'll need equipment or some such.

That said, people need to treat {6} much different when rating compared to {2}{G}{G}{W}{W} or something. Color limits mana production heavily. Similarly {B}{B}{B} is much different than {W}{W}{W}

Urza lands, Locus, Channel, Spoils of Evil, etc.. these are all ways to produce gobs of colorless mana by turn 2-3 (among other things), further: no color weight means you can put this in any color (well duh) meaning that {U} can get an efficient huge beater where it normally might have trouble doing so.

97068: Ryusei, the Falling Star.author: car2n
97068: Ryusei, the Falling Star.text_parsed:
Let's bask in the glory that is Magic: The Gathering

This complex-yet-elegant card back was designed by Chris Rush and was for the first set originally called "The Gathering", hence "Magic: The Gathering". The idea was that every set would have it's own card back. Arabian Nights would have had a different colored back.

Only 2 other games would carry the "Deckmaster" banner: Jyhad (later called "Vampire: The Eternal Struggle", and "Netrunner").

So many years of paying and playing, so many memories stored into this simple icon.
97068: Ryusei, the Falling Star.text_posted:

Only 2 other games would carry the "Deckmaster" banner: Jyhad (later called "Vampire: The Eternal Struggle", and "Netrunner").
